3.8/5. Very interesting vulcanic soil wine from Azores. 
Quite similar with Etna Rosso, but you can taste that it is made from different grapes.
Medium bodied and medium tannic. Balanced acidity. 
Red fruit, minerals and some spices (at least pepper) on the nose. Later when it opened up, also some pyrazines.
Lingonberry, cherry, leather and very interesting saline character on the palate. 
A little bit flat, otherwise would deserve higher score. Also not worth to buy, with the price in Finland.

First volcanic wine 🌋 
Struck match and smoke
Lighter body than I was expecting (light to medium)
Sour cherry and other red fruit
Nice minerals and salt
Lots of subtle layers
Thick legs
Worth it! Drank slightly chilled and warmed to room temp. Fun and not one bad sip over the two days I had it open 🍷

Lovely drinkable wine, great bright minerality and acidity. Red fruit dominates, with some hints of spice. A fun wine — we had it with pizza on the grill with the first ramps of the season.   A perfect pairing.

I know. I love living on an island. But my island was created by us. (As in God created the world but the Dutch created the Netherlands.) (We did.) 
This island was created by natural force. The Azores are an archipelago of volcanic islands in the Atlantic Oceans. Plate tectonics rule! I haven’t got a clue which grape are used but today I don’t mind. This expresses soil and place so incredibly well. If you like terroir wines you have to try this. Bottled crushed salted volcano porn.

Portugal's answer to Etna Rosso is this wild blend from the volcanic slopes of the Azores. Mix of Aragonês, Agronómica, Castelão, Malvarisco, Merlot, Touriga Nacional, Saborinho, Syrah and others 🍇. Nose of red cherry, cranberry, cloves, saltwater taffy, dry bramble vegetal notes, beeswax candles. Softer palate than expected, prickly acid and spicy minerality, cranberry sauce, soft but grippy tannins. Dry and lingering finish. All from only large steel tanks and gravity. 3.75 ⬆️ for fun factor and re-buy.

Clear ruby red ​​color

Nose with very specific notes of drunken cherry, blood-like and weak clove

Very fresh taste accompanied with a medium texture. Ripe tannins are well integrated with pleasant acidity. A lot of saltiness in the taste accompanied with  cherry, berry jam and black plum

Prominent medium to long aftertaste

Pale garnet hue. Medium nose cherry strawberry leather mushroom.

Dry, medium acidity, body, tannins. Medium flavour intensity and finish. Leather earthy cherry cranberry palate.

Only one one from the island on an extensive Portuguese menu, which haven’t tried before. Description of being volcanic knew be right up my street. Minerality and earthy combined with vibrant fruit and decent complexity - 4.0

Field blend (kind of) from the Azores Wine Company. 

Beautiful nose that lasts for ages, purely volcanic, with ash, warm black sand, leather, tar and smoke, complemented by some very subtle darker fruits such as plum as well as black currant (imagine the Merlot shining through). Completely unique on the nose; have not had this of a true volcanic expression. Minerals galore. 

The palate is well balanced and sophisticated, following the nose, adding a backbone of red cherries and cranberries. 4.1.
Great wine. Light with good minerality a touch of sea breeze and volcanic love

Volcanic wine from the Azores. Everything but the kitchen sink in terms of grapes: Aragonês, Agronómica, Castelão, Malvarisco, Merlot, Touriga Nacional, Saborinho, Syrah and others. Aromas of red fruit, peppery spices and a distinct mineral/iodee smell. Crunchy tannins, fresh acidity and a medium finish. Probably I am biased because of the Volcanic aspect, but this does remind me of the red wines from the Etna, based on Nerello Mascalese.

A very uniquely tasting wine: aromas of saline qualities and black pepper sood out with touch of herbaceous notes of clove. Less intense primary fruit aromas of cherry and red fruit also where present. 2018 Vintage
mineral
Volcanic salt and cherry wine fest 2021.
Chipotle, smoke, black currant, leather, bell pepper; pepper. Leathery tannin structure; good concentration. Quite bitter finish

Today’s only rating
🔝🔝🔝👍
Good depth. Fruity with a mineral finish. Did want a little more out of this but that's only because I had an Etna last week :)
Irony, love it!
Super vulcanic but greatly balanced by the fruit. Cherry, cranberry, leather.

Very original blend from the Azores islands, wild nose of game, leather, lots of spices (black pepper, clove and cinnamon) overwhelming some red fruits complemented with a floral touch (dried rose) . Flavors of sour sherry, rhubarb and red currants. Return of some spices and refreshing high acidity.

A interesting wine from the Azores. 
An volcanic archipelago in the Atlantic ocean and belongs to Portugal and therefore also a member of the European union.
Vines grow on the black slopes of the volcano Ponto do Pico.
🍇 Interesting blend of Aragonés,
    Agronòmica, Castelão, Malvarisco,
     Merlot, Touriga naçional, Saborinho,
     Syrah.
👁 Light red.
👃 Red fruit... almost like a pinot noir.
👅 Yes, same intriguing impression.
      Cherry, blackberry, strawberry, nice 
      minerality... see comment
Absolutely the best red from Azores, pleasant acidity, gentle tannins, reminds Pinot Noir style. Cherry, leather, blackberry. Was great with local beef!
Volcanic wine series at Maxwell. Very acidic, earthy, light in body and medium in taste. Lighter red in color. Good mid red fruit notes, great chillable summer red.
Meaty black fruit nose with a refreshing acidity and saline character expected from these islands. Similar in style to a Chinon.

Medium ruby colour. Nose of violets, cherries, cranberries and hints of struck match. Medium (+) acid and medium grippy tannins. Flavours of cherry, cranberry, rhubarb, ash, smoke and leather. A lovely number, definitely different and all the better for it! Great

Ligh ruby color, nose with cherry alcoholic notes, iodine and clove notes. Fresh palate, medium texture with lots of salinity and fine tannins.
Moderate length
Salty, spicy
Medium tears, soft nose, plum and cherry in taste, full body

Unique but reminiscent of an Etna Rosso. Clear, med ruby w/ garnet rim. Med+ to intense red cherry, macerated strawberry, Damascus rose, earth, roasted savory herbs, smoke and sweet spice. Surprisingly, vinification is all stainless steel. Dry, but w/ plenty of crunchy red fruit. Med acid, med to med (-) tannins, med alcohol (12%). Med body, flavor intensity and length, with a pleasant savory, saline, mineral note. Super balance at 4 years and very food-friendly. Drink now, not likely to improve with further aging.
Unique and interesting but didn’t make my toes curl but I think that is more due to personal taste.  It is a leathery red with big plum and black currant  and a rounded vanilla finish.  Worth trying.

Volcanic wine from Azores. Salt, cherry. Earthy aftertaste. Not your typical wine, very good. But also, very specific. Had it with middle-eastern meats, and it’s not the best pairing. Need something lighter.

A true field blend of mostly Aragonez (Tempranillo), and some Castelao, Agronomica, Malvarisco (?), Touriga Nacional, Syrah, & Merlot. Med ruby leaning towards garnet in color. Pronounced aromas of black cherry, red cherry, black plum, jalapeño, black pepper, roasted red bell pepper, cedar, & other campfire / forest floor notes. Palate mirrors aroma - rich earthy qualities from start to finish. What a crazy & spicy wine! Begs for some BBQ. Delicious but not very approachable.

Acidic and light, slightly bitter 
Smooth with a little tiny bit of leather at the end. Minerality throughout is delicious! 
Would pair lovely with an acidic food like blistered tomatoes
Dark red purple tinted. Aroma of oak, sweet cherry, ripe dark fruit, umami, sulfur and pepper. Dry, medium body, long with predominantly taste of dark fruit.

Blend from the Azores of 14 varieties.
Light ruby color.
Red fruit, mon cheri's, herbs
Fresh, a bit spicy and salty
Not bad but a bit too much acidity

This is a super unique, really idiosyncratic wine. Beautiful salinity and slate flavors that immediately evoke sand and salt water. It’s followed by dark berries and black pepper. It’s a relatively light bodied wine, and its unlikely origin story is fascinating.
Interesting. Black fruits. Mineral and Smokey notes. Cherries. Medium to high acidity.

It is interesting wine. And I can say - specific. 

Only your for your try, not for anyone’s description.

Enjoy 😉
From the azores a minerals and sea air tasting wine. perfect in acc with roasted beef   worth a try !!
Light in color. Translucent juice. Very aromatic but lack of layers of complexity. White flower and herbs notes but not so much berry notes. Unique wine. Grainy tannin and moderate acidity.
A fine drinking read from the Azores. Was sufficiently complex despite its young age. Hints of leather and cherry.
Spice and plum with a blackberry and leather finish
Reminds a bit of a Cabernet-Franc from Loire. Spicy, succulent, nice meeting
Different but very good. Delicate
Nice and unoaked, pretty mineral. Then... not much. Nice blend of varietals.

Interesting blend from the Azores wine company. It was recommended by the Sommelier at a Montreal resto we were at. He had us try this glass. Glad we didn’t get the bottle of it, but it was definitely a nice, fruity, fun, light bodied wine to start the night.

Not a fan of the red (although the vulcanic white is awesome) - musk, iron, and chalk mineral flavors in a cherry driven syrupy profile. Light bodied and with good acidity, it’s almost like a mineral ripe Pinot Noir, but lacking a bit more depth and complexity.

On the light side (not intended to be a negative!), red currant and cherry fruit plus some of the Azorean, volcanic character evident in the rosé sister wine. Develops a bit more body with 24 hours exposure to some air without losing freshness.

🌟3,7
The style is somehow resembling of red Vinho Verde - not everyone’s cup of tea due to lush bold body and high acidity. But it’s a curiosity, though more of a one-time thing because of the almost 20€ price.
👃🏻young, bold, ripe cherry and red plum, herbaceous with notes of green tobacco leaf, bay leaf, juniper berry
👄M+ acidity, M body, M- fruit tannins (inox only). A very gastronomic wine.
🛒🇪🇪MilVinhos
📍Azores and Bairrada tasting, 11.09.2020. The most exciting wine of the tasting

Notes from previous world. Blend of too many grapes to list, grown at base of the volcano next to the sea. Lean, smoky and rocky with some bright red fruit and spice. Salty and mineral, with some characteristics of an Etna red but lacking some of the ripeness and structure.

Azores wine! 

My first wine from this volcanic Portuguese Island. This special soil is very important for the wine as well. 
A blend from a large number of different grapes. 

Quite surprised on the wine, a real beauty, lighter red in colour. Lovely nose with fruits, spices and fine wood. On the palate red berries, cherry, strawberry blackberry, added with nice spices, minerality, a touch of wood, fine tannins and a smooth finish. Like this wine and I concur with the vivino average.

🍇local red varieties Castelao, Touriga Nacional, Aragonês, Agronómica, Castelão, Malvarisco, Saborinho + some adapted Syrah and Merlot.
Production: grapes are harvested at different times and fermented in 1 small stainless tank (600-1000l). No pumps, gravity flow No oak, pure expression of red wine face of the Pico island. Bottle # 2921 out of 3330
Notes: sour cherry, clove, iodine, hint of old paddle leather. Salinity, freshness and soft tannins.Surprisingly persistent.

This is surprisingly lovely! Very fruity and secondary aromas on the nose, with black cherries and forest floor, blackberry and mushroom, leather notes. The palate is light, dry, fruity — red cherry, cranberry, à touch of pepper.
Full of minerality and red fruit, incredible wine
Dry yet balanced with fruit. A little dirt added to black cherry & a hint of sea air. Love this wine - the rose does not disappoint either!

Fresh, dominant red fruits character, mainly raspberry, lots of red bell pepper with just a hint of leather. Very light, almost watery. Good companion to the magnificent spicy steak of Associação Agrícola

Fresh red cherry and red plum on the nose with underlying leather and game notes and a mineral edge. Medium bodied with a high acidity. The fruit on the palate is a bit darker and the leather and gamey notes remain. Slightly rustic in style but an interesting wine with some depth and complexity.

Worth tasting, but beware. It's not a common type of wine. I would position it closer to a Beaujolais or a red Verde, or Vinhão, as it's usually called in Northern Portugal. But we are talking of a wine made in vey harsh conditions, volcanic soil, by the sea, lacking the heat and sun most wines get. Think of it as an experience!
Rather disappointing red blend from highly proclaimed producer. Aragones, Agronomica, Castelao, Malvarisco, Merlot, Touriga Nacional, Saborinho, Syrah and other 🍇🍇🍇. Light body and high in acidity.

It’s a good surprise wine, with lower 11.5% alcohol for a Portuguese wine. It is unusual and pleasantly so. Definitely worth trying again!

Not a great bottle. Cant believe that average price is £20.Not a lot of flavour. If I want something from the Azores I'll listen to Nelly Furtado.

Very light with minimum  nose. Dry red berries with a very refreshing acid. Light wine to be compared with Beaujolais an PN. Maybe not as good but still interesting.

Totally different from what I have tasted till now. This red wine, produced in Azores volcanic earth, is very mineral and seems metalic. Not very persistent but great with Azorean typical food, such as "cozido das Furnas".
A light but fruity, spicy and mineral red cuvée from the volcanic island of Azores with cherry, cranberry, clove and salt on the nose. I just love volcanic wines 😍
Perfume on the nose. Herbaceous, grass, green pepper on the palate. Medium length.

Red blend from the Azores. Fresh cherry nose, smooth tannins and  Atlantic salinity. A little lacking in oomf and complexity compared with listan negro from the canaries. Don't see the Nerello Mascalese comparisons at all. Suspect their white wines would have more character. Also (understandly) overpriced for Portugal.

I really liked this surprising wine. Lighter than I expected but so smooth and extremely food friendly. I had it with fresh greens from our farm with wasabi radishes over the top, and this wine paired beautifully. Truly brought out the mustardy character of the greens but stood up to the spice of the radishes. 

Alone, it has beautiful complexity without being big. Tart cherry, cranberry, earthy, minerals, and lightly herbaceous. Every sip brings something new. Very enjoyable

Very nice, very different. fresh, dry, mineralic red wine with notes of sourcherries, white pepper, mint and ash. Drink it colder than you would usually drink red wine and pair it with fresh/raw tuna, carpaccio or beef tartar. Kirsche Mineralien Rauch Pfeffer Salz Asche

Very different, incredibly fruity, cherry, iodine and clove notes comes through. Tastes quite like a Berry juice, tart, dry and full of sharp berries. Great with heavy lamb meat.

Ruby colour. Blackcurrant, Dark fruit, plum, green leaf, licorice and chocolate aromas. Good balance and acidity. Medium tannins and alcohol. Good all around Bordeaux. Slightly on the rustic side.
Full bodied dark red, almost purple colored. Aromas of blackcurrant, blackberry and plum combines nice with the spices of cinnamon, vanilla and oak. Pairs well with rack of lamb.

Pronounced.
Black cherry, blackberry, plum, pepper, capsicum. Vanilla, charred wood, smoke. Good tertiary development - tobacco, tar, barn yard, earth, vegetal.

Palate is dry, high grippy tannins, pronounced flavours, very black fruit driven. Fully bodied with a long finish. Lacked some complexity. 

Very enjoyable wine. Won’t develop into outstanding but good value for money.

This very good Bordeaux blend from Baron de Rothschild’s Mouton Cadet vineyard is terrific value. Super dry, medium tannins, medium-full body. Blackcurrant, blackberry, dark plum, plenty of leather, tobacco and oak notes. Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet franc and merlot. Paired well with slow cooked lamb and would go equally well with any rich red meat dishes.

Great QPR.  Pronounced black cherry, black plum, touch of blackcurrant, pepper and some leafy notes, nutmeg, cedar, tobaccos, hint of tar and barnyard.

Med+ palate follows with some red fruit and smoke, hi acid/tannin and med+ alcohol.  full body.  med+ finish

Excellent, rich, still flaunting the fruit and leaning heavy on the earthy notes. Tobacco leaf, blackberry jam, baking spices on the nose;  scratchy tannin, cherry, chokeberry, blackcurrant on the palate. A fair amount of acidity to balance the tannin and alcohol. A lovely pairing with lamb sirloin and chocolate-covered strawberries for dessert!

Good wine, ruby ​​red, full-bodied. On the nose aromas of ripe black and red fruits with hints of spice. In the mouth it is dry, balanced, with flavors of plums, licorice, red fruits, leather and wood notes. Powerful and persistent finish.

A wine with a relatively low price compare to the same class of table wine but high in quality. It only costed 150 HKD. After the exposure of air for about an hour, lots of dark fruit taste attacks my palate. What a monster!

The wine robes with ruby red color, releasing rich and mellow scents with floral and fruity notes. The palate shows power and structure with layers of black berry, cassis, blueberry, cherry and black pepper underlying with silky tannins and mild acidity. Freshness and richness are interplaying on the persistent finish with spicy accent and depth.

13.5% ABV with 2 g/L sugar.
Aromas of oak, vanilla and blackberry on the nose. The palate adds to the nose, plum, tobacco and slight smokiness. 
It finishes long. Well structured, fairly rich and flavourful with a pleasant mouthfeel. $24.95 Cdn for the bottle but of course at the restaurant $16 a glass. I was surprised, it is a pretty nice “ by the glass” wine.

My first french wine in a long  time. 

I’ve been mostly disappointed by the entry level offerings that Checkers stock in their “Wines of the world “ range. This mouton cadet is one of the more premium offerings. A blend of cs and merlot, from medoc. 

The seriously old dirt from Vilafonte I sampled yesterday, bears an uncanny resemblance to this Mouton Reserve. 
 Cheers!

You don't go wrong when you chose a bottle of Mouton Cadet Réserve. This wine by Baron Philippe de Rothschild is a very pleasant Medoc. The colour is ruby with purple gradations. On the nose, the wine offers a bouquet of fresh red and black fruits but also notes of caramel and spices.  On the palate, this wine is a tasty, racy and expressive medoc that shows a lot of character. It has a slightly acidic finish.
The beautiful aroma changes its characters when time passes on. It's good to appreciate both the changing taste and passing time.

A nice wine but a bit pricey for what you get.  Flavors of plum, cherry, berry, oak, spices and vanilla.
Ruby red-pink, bit alcoholic nose, aromas of sour red fruits and mild spices. Medium body, nice acidity, medium finnish.
Got in a “lucky bag” pretty textbook Medoc, raspberry, red plum, blackcurrant, lots of cedar and smoke , grippy tannins.

Deep ruby colour on its appearance. On the nose, blackberry, plum, raspberry, blueberry, cherry, licorice, earthy, pepper, tobacco, cedar, vanilla, and oak. Bling tasting 6/6 - wotn
With purple hues and medium alcohol, medium viscosity.
a blend of 65% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 15% Cabernet Franc from multiple appellations throughout Bordeaux.
Black cherry, black fruits, oak and tobacco fill the nostrils.
On the palate, the black fruits really come through, and after aerating for a bout half hour the complexity of the flavours changes and becomes more palatable.
High acidity, full bodied with astringent tannins, this was the star of the show.

👀 Dark deep intense red colour and medium legs.
👃🏻 Plum, blackberry, slight minerality, bit of red fruit. Not too intense.
👅 More plum, blackberry, cassis and mild spice, minerality, some red berries. Medium acidity and dry but quite tannic. Medium to thin bodied, feels thin in the mouth. Possibly some mint and faint licorice. Cab Franc evident.
✍🏻 Pleasant balance of red and dark fruit, not too intense flavours, quite tannic but fruity with a lingering finish, drinks easily.

Happy Bordeaux Sunday everyone. Celebrating England's thrilling win in the cricket world cup & Lewis Hamilton's British GP victory 🇬🇧. Classic Bordeaux blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc from the Medoc. Dark dense ruby with nose of smoky, earthy dark fruits. Dry, high acidity, medium+ body with quite chewy tannins. Dark plum, cassis & blackberry flavours with a medium+ spicy finish. Paired nicely with home-made beef pie & purple sprouting broccoli 😁 3.7⭐

🍷 In the glass, a deep scarlet with purple tones and established legs 

👃 Redcurrants, strawberry laces, Eucalyptus and hints of mint chocolate chip ice cream in the sniffy sniff 

👅 In the mouth, viscose with strong tannins. Blackberries, concentrated Blackcurrants, aniseed and a very wonderful soft, tongue tingling finish 

👍 Impressive wine! Powerful tannins engulf and coat inside you mouth, with expressive fruit flavours and a softness which is indescribable... Give this a try if you see one!

Thought I would hate it but I didn’t. Little sister of big name Mouton Rotschild, this Medoc is very enjoyable. Blackcurrant, cassis, blackberry, loads of Morello cherries. This wine lives up to the name of its Bordeaux appellation which is famous for wines of great aging potential. Having spent almost ten years in a bottle, the wine's still intact thanks to its high quality structure which does impress this taster. Color gamut is that of mature wine. So are very well rounded remarkably soft tannins. Elegant Medoc nose, overall very palatable wine which went really well with the rump of lamb.

The wine has an attractive, youthful colour with cherry highlights and a nose that is both powerful and refined, displaying distinct red berry fruit, blackcurrant and blackberry aromas. The attack is full and massive, building on rich, rounded tannins that support well-developed fruit flavours.

As this wine breathes it reveals it quality.  It's delicate mineral nose finds an unusual graphite midrange followed by a oak-toasted breath-of-vanilla finish. Let it breathe first because first indications are that this one is past its prime, but don't be fooled.

Oaky purple, unpretentious nose with soft blackberry. Lovely balanced wood and tannins, medium  full bodied with dark fruit and gentle tannins tickling the tongue. Juicy, highly satisfying. Medium finish.

Really nice wine slightly pasted it's date but still really good. Saved it from my fathers cellar and now really glad I did. Friend mentioned a graphite taste that once I closed my eyes I could pick it to. Definitely going to enjoy the other bottles I have.

Clear, deep ruby red with a bright rim. Clean, tonnes of plum and blackberry. Dry, medium body, high acid, slightly thin in flavour. Blackberry, blackcurrant, soft leather and pencil shavings. Some delicate spices and minerality. Medium plus finish.
Wonderful, jammy. Smooth round flavours of dark cherries and plums. Light tannins. Can't stop rolling this around in my mouth.
Nice wine from the medoc. Has the characters of leather, liquorice and gentle oak. Develops well in the glass. Good entry example.

This is at best a good house wine, it lacked any real identity of its own, it has a slight berry flavour but nothing that was instantly recognizable. I opened the bottle and poured a glass and let it sit for a while, it was a Friday night so pizza was on order and all I really wanted was something red, which perfectly describes what I got. I doubt whether treating this wine any different would have altered its end result so I was just happy to drink it for what it was, a tasty enough none descriptive red.
Austere is the word, tight, grippy tannins, even after a full day of decanting. There's some fruit, but it's hard to find. Not worth your time or effort, unless austere and grippy is your thang!
Blueberries on the nose.

3.75; La Gorre has a very attractive bouquet of black cherries, cassis is a bit leathery, slightly oakd,  that is well defined and opens nicely in the glass. The palate is medium-bodied with fine, supple tannins. This is a well-crafted Cru Bourgeois. Drink now, but leave the bottle open for a couple of hours, or decant.
I had this Wine on nice summer night in front of a warm fire with a good friend.

3.7 - Pretty good value for a Bordeaux! I don't find myself saying that often. This is showing very nice development of aromas, with reduced black cherries and blackberries, hints of cedar, tobacco, and prunes. The palate is beginning to soften, while the fruit raisinates and merges with the oak and tannin. This is a more robust style than the others it was tasted alongside, and while not outstanding is in a good place right now. I say drink up!
Second time on this one. Opens up into a really nice Medoc. Paired beautifully with lasagna!  Will buy again.
Subtle cigar box and pencil shavings. Yum.
Incredible floral nose, violets and rose petal. Dry dark red currants with substantial tannins.

Deep ruby colour with a dark core. Pushing into the nose are slighted stewed black cherry and black berry backed by hints of mushroom, black pepper, cedar and lingering minty note. Dry on the palate with thick ripe tannin and balancing fresh acidity forming a full bodied flavourful mouthfeel that lasts into a long finish of fruity black tea. A great value for the quality! I was pleasantly surprised! Smoked Gouda anyone?

Expected more from this wine being a 2009 Cru Bourgeois. Firm tannins and a bit austere when first opened. Definitely opened up after a few hours but found the fruit flavours lacking, surprising given it is 55% Merlot. Would probably benefit from a few more years cellaring.
Ruby colour with red berries on the nose, leather and spice aromas. Tannins are rounded and the finish very balanced. Excellent with chicken. A really good find, and great value for money.
Very nice on the nose, great value

Number 2 of my half term treats!  Tried this when I decanted it about 2 and a half hours ago, and it has opens up and softened. The aroma has strengthened with lots of black plum, leather and oak smoke. A really deep purple colour. On its own a little tannic and 3.6⭐️.  With Cambazola soft blue cheese and pistachio nuts it is awesome, maybe towards a 4.5⭐️ so I've averaged it. At £14.99 a very good price. Would be great with a slow roast lamb leg or casserole. Blackberry & raspberry in the taste. Silky finish

3,8 ⭐ It was at the end of the wine harvest, and of cause everybody was tired. Nevertheless the owner unlocked his tastfull wine tasting room, next to his cellar with the barrels. After I tasted 3 wines I was about to buy, when a tractor load of grapes arrived and my host invited me to join and watch. It was very interesting, even if you have seen it many times.
Deep red. Nose of blackfruit. Flavours of blackberry, vanilla and oak. Would become even better with more aging.
Despite having more Merlot, it seems to be dominated by the cab sauv. Nice spices and black fruits.
Great but needs longer finish

Deep ruby red colour with beautiful aroma,of red fruit and floral herbs on the nose, lovely polished and fine-grained tannin texture on the palate with elegant flavours of plums, raspberries,  and leather,  giving long finish and a wonderful.aftertaste

This merlot dominated wine (50/45/5 PV/CS) has a nose of blackcurrant, black cherries and some lavender and leather. Medium + bodied, bone dry, with gripping tannins and medium+ acidity, it displays flavors of black cherries. The finish is slightly acidic and earthy with some peppery notes. An ok wine with perhaps little potential. 2.5 stars.

Tasted in 2021, and probably 5-7 years too early. This one was made for ageing. 

Very fresh, lively deep scarlet color with no border orange hues.
Blueberry, strawberry jam and hint of leather on the nose.

On palate, Cab dominates: strong entry and medium finish. Merlot somehow is missing to fill the middle. Gripping tannins, pronounced acidity and potent but well-integrated alcohol. At ten years, this tastes and feels like a young wine.

A fine pairing with Beef Provencal.

OMG. Love this merlot heavy blend. Nose with heavy pomegranate and chocolate married to a figgy beast. Velvet tannins with lovely tobacco and earth and gooseberry to a short but delicious cocoa finish

This beauty should ago no longer. The tannins are wonderfully soft. Lotta aromas of leather, smoke, cherry with hints of chocolate and earth. Definitely not as intense in the palate- it’s a bit of a letdown. But definitely better than a kick in the pants so I’ll have another glass!

A herbaceous nose with hints of aged oak. Initial flavours of currant and violets when the wine hits the palate. Flavours fuse into notes of herbs, cocoa, and leather adding complexity. Tannins have a chalky feel. Finish is long and lingering.
89/100. Showing well as one would expect of the vintage. A tad unbalanced but overall good bang for the buck.

Deep turbid ruby-red. Strong aromatic intensity: red fruit, ripe plum, vanilla, chocolate and hints of bell pepper. In the mouth, medium, high tannins, but a bit too outstanding, full bodied, with oak and jam flavors. Complex, but still with room to improve in the cellar. 4.1

Cuvée from Nero d'Avola, Nerello Mascalese, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon.

Ruby red with purple hues.

 Opulent and at the same time gently balanced bouquet of dark berries, pomegranate, strawberry, forest berries, cherry jam, black chocolate, raisins.  Candied notes and roasted aromas.

 Warm, opulent taste on the palate, delicate melting and round tannins.

Very nice southern Italian red wine (Sicily). Made from Nero D’Avola and a very tiny bit of Cabernet Sauvignon. Carefully Hand harvested grapes in small boxes. Aged in oak drums for 18 months. Very smooth. Dark fruit, fig, chocolate, tobacco, vanilla, hints of leather. Firm but not heavy. Medium to soft tannines. Very balanced. Very smooth. Rich taste. Lots of colours. No acidity. Very professional made. Because it’s not to heavy it can be combined with a lot of dishes (meat, puoltry and fish). Enjoy!

Deep dark red. Nose is Elegant and complex with fruit notes such as cassis and cherries, cedar, tobacco and coffee. Palate is rich, with a smooth texture and excellent balance. Very persistent and concentrated finish.

Deep ruby red. Medium oaky nose with blackberry and caramel fragrance in second layer. On palate from the very beginning tannins and mineral notes build the dry character of the wine,’ fruity notes in the backstage. Plums and raisins. Elegant and balanced. Very much Amarone style. Astonishing but fascinating.

Opened another bottle of Amasso. Should have waited longer, as the last bottle was opened only a couple of months ago. But still this is one of my favourite southern italian reds. Lots of red fruit and a smooth finish. Less oak then I sensed the last time. I am still in love.

Nose👃🏻: leather, oak, cocoa, tobacco, black currant, blackberry, violet jam. 
Mouth 👄: leather and vanilla with chocolate, blackberry, black currant, chokeberry finish. Nice tannis, great body, long finish.

Founded in 2000 in Santa Ninfa, Sicily. Ammasso is their flagship wine. 🍇Nero d'Avola, Nerello Mascalese, Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. Aged 8-10 months in French and American oak. Deep ruby colour. Aromas of toasted oak, plums, tobacco, candied fruit and hints of vanilla. On the palate toasted oak, plums, spices, candied fruit, blackcurrants, chocolate 🍫 and hints of vanilla. A spicy and complex Sicilian wine. A med+ body with med velvety tannins. A med+ acidity and a spicy med+ 🏁. Pair with 🍖 or 🍝.

This is one big hefty wine. Very cherry on the nose, with cherry and strawberry flavours backed up by wood / cigar smoke, earthy notes, a bit of chocolate, sugars, and clove. It was difficult to know what to do with this, to be honest: I couldn't think of much food it would pair well with, but drinking it on its own was quite a feat! Especially as the alcohol really shone through (14.5%). This is a good good wine, but make sure you drink it with something that'll balance it out.

A mix of Nero d'Avola, Nerello Mascalese, Merlot and cabernet sauvignon. This wine is produced through a traditional technique called "ammasso". Grapes are displayed in a sigle layer and left dry for 4 weeks in a controlled temperature chanber "fruttaia". Aged for 8/10 months in a toasted oak casks. A balanced wine with notes of red mature fruits, spices and intense tannins. A full bodied elegant wine that can be paired with roast, barbecued meat, red meat (lamb) and spinach gnocchi.

I query why people use the term ‘entry level’ for a wine of this quality. Sure, it’s got superior older brothers and sisters but it’s €15.00 which is a decent price for a bottle of wine and for most drinkers this would be a distinctive treat. I guess some people nip to the pub for a pint of Petrus and think nothing of it! This is gorgeous, rich, lush and smooth. There is a strong presence of dark and red fruit with some wonderful autumn leaves and organic notes - it’s highly sophisticated and a privilege.

Tasting Note taken at WSET L3 course by Wine Courses Barcelona:

Appearance 👀: med/purple

Nose👃: med+ intensity, developing, plum, pepper, prune, blackberry

Palate 😛: dry, med acidity, med tannins, high alcohol, med+ body, med+ intensity; blackberry, black currant, cherry, dark chocolate, pepper, coffee, med+ finish

⚖️ Conclusion - BLIC: 
Balance🟢; Length🟢; Intensity🟢; Complexity🟡

▶️  very good quality

✅ drink now, aging potential 

Cheers - Salud - Prost - Santé - Saúde

Powerful and quite unusual for a Priorat. Dark ruby. Dominated by herbal, earthy and woody aromas. Forest, autumn leaves. Some black fruit and almost no spice which I'd normally expect from a Priorat. Fruity on the palate with strong tannin.

Well balanced, drink it a bit cold, smooth nice full flavor without being dominant, mix between 50% strong full taste and 50% of easy to drink, so combined , smooth full wine not to easy so nice balanced taste. Nice class wine

Great wine from a great producer again. Not as bold as the others that I've tasted from them but lovely nonetheless. 

On the nose: Blueberries, and blackberries, black pepper, oregano, and liqourice. 

On the palate: Blacberries dominating the fruits. Oregano, roses, blackberries, violet.

Quite earthy, juicy, and a bit of spice. Lovely acidity.
First priorat ever. Deep purple. Blackcurrant cherry berry plum leather smoky meaty and savory notes. High tannin medium+ body and finish.
Black currant, black cherry, dried plum. Mushrooms, nice spiciness. Velvety tannins, beautiful mineral notes in the long finish.
Priorst produces some complex reds full of character and body. This was lighter than expected but with a fruity nose, medium to strong tannins, hints of cherry on the palate.
Fruity. Red fruit y Rosemary
3.9 lighter expression of Priorat. Very well balanced, good acidity structure, fine finish.
Very full bodied. A chonky wine with a hint of stank. Low sulphite. Montepulciano-ish... Would drink again. Needs a good two hours to open up. A bit unapproachable  otherwise.
Nice one. I like the leather and tobacco nose. Its not that heave but still its not a mild wine. Nice piece of stuff.

Bold and rich full bodied organic wine. Had it with Tapas in Barcelona. Alot of rich fruits and 
berries.

Beautiful deep violet color
Mint, pepper, with black fruit, a bit earthy, lots of oak.  Very complex aromas. Firm tannins, but a smooth long finish. Really enjoyed it.
Cassis Burberry raspberry smooth
Cherry, raspberry and blackberry with a taste of leather and oak. Complex with earthy flavours. Full or medium bodied and deep red. Off-dry, acidic and smoothly tannic. Long and warm finish.
Great Priorat. Dark ruby color. Aroma of sweet cherries, licorice and mocha. On the palate coffee and cherries. Velvety finish. Perfect for steak.

I really like this wine. Big and fruity. Will look out for it in the uk

Tapas bar in Barcelona
Dark berries, oak. Needs decanting #clubamaronesweden
Bold and elegant with a good amount of depth
Dark fruit, violets with a bit of forest floor and green pepper on the nose.  Pepper, cherries and berries on the palate.  Firm, strong tannins that are velvety.  Medium finish.
Deep red colour. Soft medium bodied wine with strong red fruit flavours (cherry and strawberry come to mind). Quite mild in tannins and acidity. Some pepper in the finish.

Young Priorat. Modern approach (earlier picking) more restrained style.

👁clear medium purple colour

👃clean medium intencity primary aromas of black fruit (cassis, plum); red fruit (cherry); touch of herbaceous aromas it tomato leaf. Some oak aromas (smoke) this wine is still developing

👄dry, medium acidity, high tannin, high alko, medium+ body, medium+ flavour intencity, long finish. Flavours underlined above.

To be decanted for at least 2 hours. Can sting today and also has potential for ageing.
Plum, blackberry, some earthy minerals

Gorgeous slate nose, carignan shows but with richness and elegance. Really pretty and an homage to the fruit.  Gorgeous leather and blue black fruit flavors with modest oak. A lighter and purer style priorat and fun to drink.

This is a nice, very smooth red blend of Grenache and Carignan. It was about $15.00 a bottle so IMO a great value. This wine had great red fruit taste, balanced tannins and a very smooth & Linh aftertaste. Had it with Iberian ham, fried artichokes and caprese salad.

Excellent very expressive full body dry red Spanish wine. Intense deep red colour. Red cherry, leather and dark chocolate in taste. High acidity. Solid and expressive tannins. 14% alcohol level. Long spicy and oaky finish. It isn't everyday drinking wine. I think, it should be good with roasted pork or beef . In my opinion it would be very good pairing.

Deep purple with reddish rim.  Ripe red fruits with strawberries with some hints of flint and savory notes.  Medium body.  Low acidity.  More flint, gamey savory notes and terrior on the palate but well balanced with red fruits.  Medium but well integrated tannins.  Length 3-4s.

Manure and barnyard....eases into a grassy nose. Deep purple like my first prom dress in the late 80s.  Burnt wood, pepper (the spice not the pizza topping) fig and balsamic.  Spanish wine aged in French oak makes for a sexy mouth feel.
By the glass at Tapas Tapas, Arenas-Madrid. Wonderful wine, full body

First one to taste the Tros de Clos 2014 !

👀 Clear, deep ruby

👃🏽 Clean, med + intensity. 
Blueberry, black plum, black cherry, red fruits, strawberry, cranberry, vanilla, cedar, medicinal, tobacco

👅 Dry, high acidity, high tannins, high alcohol (14.0%), med + body, aggressive mousse, pronounced intensity and long finish

🌟 Balance, intensity, length and complexity —> outstanding!

🧐 Drink now but has potential
Trying this vintage again, I’m struck by how refined and balanced this is.  Beautifully crafted.  Even at $22, this has excellent QPR

Rather good

Spicy and punchy like an overpriced Shiraz.

I love Priorat every time!

dried plums with sugar icing on top, ripe cherries, you think it’s vanilla, but it’s more of a crème brûlée once you let it breathe, a heavy load of sugar spice, that’s quite delicate, just a little note of cherry tomatoes and veal — very well balanced and rich, exquisite and intriguing
Inky purple color, nose of floral shop peat, lovely blackberry and dark fruits on palate. Definitely worth a repeat!

fruity, dry, nice body, overall delucious and great value.

New to wines of Catalunya so this was one of the strangest wines I've ever tried! The minerals of the rocky terroir are definitely present. Quite acidic as well. Sulphurous mineral nose and fruity body. I would be curious to try a bottle with more age.
Ruby colored, medium to full bodied, medium + acidity, grenache and carignan blend, 14% ABV. Red fruit and plum notes.  Needs food to enjoy.

This priorat needs 2 hours to open up. Dark-purple and thick in the glass; light strawberry nose; intense blueberry flavour, some spices and a juicy long finish with lots of tannins.
The nose brings a old barn in a green meadow on a misty morning. Nice legs, beautiful deep purple color and a solid mouth feel. Plums, dark  spice and peppered mushrooms. Very nice.
Intense purple-red color in the glass! On the mose ruity bouquet, cherries, red berry, lavender, rosemary and liquorice! On the palate juicy, well dosed and with a fresh, fruity finish! Cheers!

QPR: worth 13,90 €uros (Vivino's average price)

Another vintage: yes
Comment: another good white wine from Priorato, I like 'em...

Slight hint of smoke and vanilla on the nose. Blackberry and spice on the tongue. Medium plus body. Medium plus acidity. Medium tannins. A touch high on alcohol. Good wine, but a tad overpriced

A big nose not really backed up by the palate but not bad at all for a Priorat at this price. The drips show themselves in the daintiness of this wine. Blueberries and young dark fruits crushed into something rocky.

3.7 87p. Spicy and bold nose with dark dusty fruit, violets, oak and horse stable (brettanomyces?). 

Raspberries, green stalks and oak on the palate. Off-dry. 

International style. Given that this is Priorat, it lacks in  structure. 

14 % abv.

A 55/45 blend of Carignan and Grenache with a jammy nose and notes of blackberries and salted black licorice on the palate. Stylistically big and bold, but not nearly as concentrated as many other higher quality Priorat reds. Priorat wines can be more international in style than just about any other European wine region. Sort of a New World region surrounded by Old World Europe. 

08/10/17 - more depth, structure and nuance. Substantial improvement. Just under 4🌟.

Appearance clear, deep ruby color. On the nose unclean (not faulty), medium intens aromas. Blackberries, black cherry, black plum, blackcurrant, raspberry, white pepper, vanilla, earth, smoke, oak wood, dark chocolate, animality. On the palate: dry, medium acidity, high tannins, medium+ bodied wine. In flavour: blackberries, blackcurrant, white pepper vanilla, earth, smoke, oak wood, dark chocolate. Medium finish with red  /dark fruity, oak aromas. A good solid wine from Priorat!

From a favorite Spanish producer. Silky smooth, black fruit pink peppercorn, sarsaparilla, cinnamon and a hint of charred oak, darn good. Great warmth, silky tannins and a long finish that keeps coming back.

Not quite at my expected priorat standards. Deep rubi red, aromas of tart red fruit, leather, tobacco and animal skin that mellows with aeration. Palate is medium bodied, with mid minus acidity and edgy medium plus tannins. Not that classic Priorat style here. Still ok to drink. Nothing to brag about.

Blackberry and cherry combine with mineral and earth notes and on the palate. Medium body, moderate tannins, good acidity and good balance. Decent medium length finish. Try pairing with roast beef.  Fair QPR at $19.

Will try this Priorat again. Not complex but well-balanced and ridiculously easy to drink.

Cloudy (unfiltered) deep cherry red with slight violet rim. Inviting nose of mature red fruit. Well balanced fruit, acidity and tannins, medium long finish.

2014. Organic. 50% Grenache / 50%  Carignan. Fermented in Stainless steel and barrelled for 9 months in French oak.

I must have bought a case of flawed bottles of this wine: volatile acidity and some other fermentation issues destroyed the virtues of this otherwise highly rated red … I tasted it a couple of years ago and thought time would resolve these issues, but it actually became worse. Still drinkable, but far from good. What a pity.

This is a bit atypical for Priorat.  Lots of Mediterranean minerals on nose and palate, but a bit brash like a Cotes du Rhone Villages with similar varietals. Still, the Spanish character comes through in the subtle oak overlaying the firm tannins and tight acidity.  Decant this at least one hour, and stack a couple bottles in the cellar.

Lovely nose of dark fruits, salty caramel, banana and earthy notes. Dry, med bodied, med acids, subtle tannins. Slight oakiness on palate which follows the nose a bit fruitier. Minerality on middle palate. As some have noted quite atypical priorat. Bit watery finish, not as bold as priorats usually are, dried fruits missing. Still enjoyable red from the area. On blind tasting wouldnt guess on priorat!

Old world concentrate. My first Priorat and I'm digging it. Nose is animal skins, tobacco and farmyard in a subtle and great way that masks the ripe fruit till aeration. The mouth is nicely concentrated dark fruit. It's got secrets and makes you work for them. A bit hot with heavy tannins and acid. Maybe it would be nicely melded in a few more years

2.8

On next sip this repeats.
Finish is low intense, slighly velvet with acidity

Nice thick extracted Priorat, funky barnyard nose made in a French Bordeaux style.  Let breath 1 hour and the nose returns to a nice tone.  A food wine for sure, paired with pork tenderloin in a rich mushroom sauce.
